headline: Crown Minerals Third Reading Reverses Offshore Exploration Ban as NZ Eyes Energy Security; Public Service and ECE Reforms Progress to Committee
summary: Parliament's sitting focused on major energy policy and governance moves. The Crown Minerals Amendment Bill sailed through its third reading, reversing the 2018 offshore exploration ban and signaling a pivot toward domestic gas and investment, while the Public Service Amendment Bill and Education and Training (Early Childhood Education Reform) Amendment Bill advanced to committee, and a broad Regulatory Systems omnibus bill began its journey through the House. Debates exposed sharp divides over climate risk, fiscal discipline, and the role of regulation in public services.

topicSummaries.topic: Crown Minerals Amendment Bill Third Reading: Reverses 2018 offshore exploration ban, expands permit access across New Zealand
topicSummaries.content: The Crown Minerals Amendment Bill was advanced to its third reading, reversing the 2018 ban on new petroleum exploration outside onshore Taranaki and restoring a framework intended to promote exploration and energy security. Supporters argued that the prior ban reduced investment and worsened energy shortages, emphasizing the need for diverse energy sources and domestic gas as a stabilizing factor for prices and electrification. Opponents warned of climate risks, potential increases in emissions, and a drift toward fossil-fuel dependence, arguing the changes could threaten international climate commitments and trade relationships. The bill was put forward as a pragmatic shift to attract investment and meet energy demand, with most changes to take effect immediately and a broader implementation plan outlined for September. The outcome: party-line passage, with the bill moving to enactment following the third-reading vote.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr MEGAN WOODS (Labour—Wigram)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill that we are debating the third reading of is a very potent symbol of the shambles that this Government is when it comes to energy policy.

keyExchanges.speaker: SIMON COURT (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill does nothing to increase our energy security.

topicSummaries.topic: Public Service Amendment Bill: Merit-based appointments, contestable CEO reappointments, and reduced DEI provisions
topicSummaries.content: The Public Service Amendment Bill moved from first reading to committee consideration, aiming to sharpen the Public Service’s focus on performance, merit-based appointments, and accountability. Key proposals include making chief executive reappointments contestable, reintroducing involvement of the Public Service Commissioner in back-office appointments, and strengthening performance management. The bill also seeks to reduce duplication in chief executive responsibilities and limits on diversity, equity, and inclusion provisions within the Act, arguing these are already addressed elsewhere in law. Critics argued the reforms could weaken pay equity protections and politicize appointments, while supporters said they would restore discipline and merit to the public service. The House proceeded to refer the bill to the Governance and Administration Committee with a four-month-and-one-day reporting deadline.

keyExchanges.speaker: CAMILLA BELICH (Labour—Nelson)
keyExchanges.quote: This government has once again put a bill before this House which takes New Zealand backwards.

topicSummaries.topic: Education and Training (Early Childhood Education Reform) Amendment Bill: First Reading and committee pathway
topicSummaries.content: The Education and Training (Early Childhood Education Reform) Amendment Bill received its first reading and was referred to the Education and Workforce Committee, with a plan to report back in four months and one day. The bill centers on establishing a Director of Regulation for ECE, streamlining licensing criteria (reducing 98 licensing criteria to a leaner set), and clarifying enforcement responsibilities. Proponents argued the regulator would ensure child safety and reduce bureaucratic burden for ECE providers, while critics warned the reforms risk undermining teacher professionalism and private sector involvement in ECE. The opposition emphasized the need for stronger support for teachers and cautioned against privatising essential early education into a new regulatory regime.

keyExchanges.speaker: HON JAN TINETTI (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: That's absolutely right: it is about profits.

keyExchanges.speaker: DR LAWRENCE XU-NAN (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: What is quite laughable about this bill is the fact that when we are looking at Cabinet papers, 'children', 'teacher', 'education' are rarely found.

topicSummaries.topic: Regulatory Systems (Internal Affairs) Amendment Bill: Omnibus reforms across 23 Acts, with regulatory modernisation goals
topicSummaries.content: The Regulatory Systems (Internal Affairs) Amendment Bill was introduced as an omnibus measure covering 23 Acts to improve regulatory effectiveness and modernise government services. It includes provisions to tighten gambling regulation (raising the age for Lotto purchases to 18+), enable broader cross-border information-sharing on objectionable material, streamline RealMe digital identity access, and update language and procedures in related acts. While most changes are technical, opponents signalled concerns about redactions in regulatory impact statements and argued for broader public consultation on fire service levies and heritage data sharing. The bill was referred to the Governance and Administration Committee with an instruction to report back and the House acknowledged ongoing scrutiny in committee.

keyExchanges.speaker: FRANCISCO HERNANDEZ (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is a distraction. It's culture war nonsense that seeks to blame the ills of modern society on the so-called DEI—diversity, equity, and inclusion—policies.

keyExchanges.speaker: HON DAVID SEYMOUR (Minister for Regulation)
keyExchanges.quote: That last speech is what can happen if you don't prepare before giving a speech.

conclusion: The day underscored a government leaning toward retooling energy security and public-sector governance, with the Crown Minerals Amendment Bill passing its third reading and signalling a new energy investment path, while public-service and ECE reforms cleared the initial hurdle and will face detailed scrutiny in committee ahead of August sittings.
